intro: Acaena anserinella, commonly known as the silverweed, is a flowering plant native to New Zealand. It is a low-growing perennial species that belongs to the family Rosaceae. The plant features dense clusters of small, yellowish flowers surrounded by bracts, which are modified leaves. Its leaves are typically trifoliate, with three leaflets that are covered in fine hairs. Acaena anserinella is adapted to grow in dry, rocky environments and is often found in alpine and subalpine regions.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena anserinella is primarily native to New Zealand. It is commonly found in the southern and western regions of the country. This plant thrives in coastal and subalpine environments. It is often seen growing in open vegetation and on rocky slopes. Acaena anserinella is an important component of the local flora and is adapted to the unique climate of New Zealand.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena anserinella was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as part of the European flora during the early colonization period. The plant has since become naturalized in several regions of the country. It is commonly found in disturbed soils and along roadsides. However, it is considered a potential weed in some areas due to its aggressive growth habits.
